awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Integrating Multiple Analyses to Understand Gene Regulatory Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Gene regulatory networks play a vital role in nearly every process of life as they are responsible for receiving environmental stimuli and translating these into activity inside the cell. In this project, the PIs will develop new strategies for computer-based modeling, and hence understanding and predicting, behavior of complex gene regulatory networks. The computer programs (algorithms) that will be developed represent a novel strategy integrating scientific discovery with computational innovation. Although the algorithm is being used to explore the gene regulatory networks of a fungal cell's response to stress it should lead to principles applicable to other biological systems. The model will be validated by comparing model predictions with data collected from experiments and this data will then be used to further refine the model. This project also includes initiatives to advance undergraduate education by employing an interdisciplinary problem-based learning approach that will be comprised of multi-state teams that also involve graduate students. 


The goal of this project is to develop a new approach for modeling gene regulatory networks. The PIs will test the hypothesis that initial experimental characterization of a network subset will permit identification of the biomolecular constituents and their connectivity, thus establishing network topology. System wide time-course measurements can then be used to refine this network into a reaction kinetic model capable of making accurate system predictions. The cell wall integrity signaling pathway of the experimentally tractable model fungus Aspergillus nidulans will serve as a model. This pathway responds to cell wall damage by activating repair mechanisms that restore cell integrity. Because protein kinases play a pivotal role in mediating cellular regulatory activities, the PIs will focus on a subset of kinases and the discovery of their associated substrates to initially assemble a rudimentary network. Subsequently the system will be experimentally perturbed for measuring its dynamic response using a robust transcriptomic, proteomic and phosphoproteomic platform. Using this data, the PIs will take a two-step approach to developing the dynamic system of coupled ordinary differential equations able to describe dynamic behavior of a model gene regulatory network. First, an ensemble approach of approximate models will be tested and refined. In the second step, the ensemble will act as the seed population for use in an evolutionary algorithm to generate a more refined and accurate model. The PIs will then validate the model by iterative comparisons of in silico predictions with experimental results.

This award is co-funded by programs in Systems and Synthetic Biology (Directorate for Biological Sciences) and Biotechnology and Biochemical Bioengineering (Directorate for Engineering).

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit. Gene regulatory networks control the way cells, in organisms ranging from yeast to man, respond to their environment and thus play a vital role in nearly every process of life. These networks are composed of numerous, highly-interconnected systems. This interconnectedness makes it tremendously challenging to understand relevant, functional relationships within these networks. Yet a robust understanding of network interconnections, and the dynamic relationships between them, would provide tremendous benefit. For example, it would allow identification of network bottlenecks, which might serve as novel drug targets, and would allow rational design of beneficial cellular behaviors for strains used in the bioprocess industry.

Our goal in this project was to develop a new methodology to study one aspect of gene regulatory networks - signal transduction. Signal transduction occurs when a cell perceives an environmental change at its surface, and then transduces or moves the signal to the nucleus where it expresses new proteins to appropriately respond to the environmental change.

In this work, we hypothesized that initial characterization of a subset of network constituents, and their connectivity, would allow us to build a rudimentary mathematical model able to predict approximate system behavior. Further, that system wide (multi-omic) measurements could be used to refine this model to make accurate system predictions. To this end, we carried out extensive phosphoproteomic analysis experiments, transcriptomic analysis experiments and began building a modeling framework to better understand our results.

This has been a true collaborative effort, with three different laboratories (UMBC, U. Conn, U. Nebraska) working together to tackle a challenging question. We carried out work in our individual labs, but met in a video conference each week to discuss data and best next-steps for the work.

 

Broader Impacts.   During this project, we have worked to develop a new process for understanding gene regulatory networks. This process is applicable in any eukaryotic system and will provide a better understanding of how environmental changes lead to cellular response. This has potential to impact many different fields ranging from agriculture to human health. In our particular project, our work will allow identification of network bottlenecks in an important fungal signaling pathway involved in cell-wall repair. These bottlenecks have the potential to serve as novel drug targets for new antifungal therapeutics. And a robust understanding of this pathway would also allow rational design of beneficial cellular behaviors for strains used in the biotechnology industry, as it would facilitate the use of optimization theory to optimize bioprocesses. This research is also having a broad impact on human capital, as it has a significant educational component with students trained in a truly interdisciplinary environment. Over the life of the project, three PhD students and seventeen undergraduates were involved. Regular interaction with the other labs involved in the project was synergistic, and particularly useful in interpreting the large data sets we generated as part of the work.
